results.title: After Cook
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Malcolm Otton and Don Murray
results.brief_description: A look at the Australian people, their character, attitudes, and way of life. Australians, in the city and the bush, are examined both at home and while enjoying their favourite pastimes. Note: A short version of 28 minutes, intended mainly for overseas viewers, was also produced, entitled ‘Everything under the sun. Commentator: John Meillon.

results.brief_description: In this film, contemporary or near contemporary figures like John Lennon and Lenny Bruce help demonstrate a hypothetical Beardsley picture of the 1980s.

results.title: After all, you're the supervisor
results.creator_credit: Roundtable Productions, Leon S. Gold and Harvey Laidman
results.brief_description: Outlines methods to assist a worker in an office environment when transferring into a managerial and supervisory position. Focuses on the value of planning, scheduling and allocating work, the importance of liaising with senior management, personnel management and discipline, evaluating suggestions, identifying problems and analysing staff needs.

results.title: Afrikaner experience: politics of exclusion
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America and Peter F. Davis
results.brief_description: Explores the history of the Afrikaners from the arrival of the Dutch in 1652 to South Africa in the 1970’s with its Apartheid System. The film is useful for its historical significance. This film contains footage from the film by Barry Callaghan entitled “South Africa/the white laager”. This film attempts to create an understanding of the historical events leading to and resulting in the Afrikaner rule of South Africa. It also examines the concept of racial superiority , and the connection between such ideology and economic profit.

results.title: Afrika: Cape Town to Cairo
results.creator_credit: Firelight Productions, Marcul Gillezeau, Ellenor Cox and Michael Davie
results.brief_description: A four part series presented by Michael Davie, a 22-year-old writer and filmmaker who set out to travel from one side of Africa to the other, the notorious 8500km journey from Cape Town to Cairo through dangerous and spectacular surroundings including Johannesburg, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Lake Malawi, Mount Kilimanjaro and Ethiopia. Arrested, beaten and interrogated numerous times on his journey, Michael reached his destination seven months after starting. The parts of the series are: Episode 1: Warriors and Witchdoctors - Michael begins by rediscovering his roots, having left the country as a childhood refugee, before travelling to Johannesburg where he meets Geraldine, a homeless prostitute and discovers the city’s violence firsthand. Episode 2: Home is Where the Landmines Are - Michael hitches to Zimbabwe and is arrested for investigating the lives of street kids before heading to Mozambique where he meets a 5 year old landmine victim and watches her learn to walk again. Episode 3: Slobs in Paradise - Michael travels Lake Malawi and Dar es Salam, investigates the heroin trade in Tanzania and climbs Mount Kilimanjaro. Episode 4: Delinquents, Tribes and Millionaires - Michael searches for the Masai warriors and meets some teenage millionaires in Kenya before sailing up the Nile to Cairo.

results.title: Africans all
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation, Julien Bryan and Greg Knowles
results.brief_description: A vast land of contradictions seen by plane from Algiers to Capetown, its varied history, primitive in the south and highly civilized in the north. The wide range of climatic and geographical conditions and their effect on the way of life. Thriving cosmopolitan cities and tiny villages; jungle growth; desert; mineral wealth and arid lands, people black and white; all are part of the African continent.
results.creator_credit_for_label: International Film Foundation, Julien Bryan and Greg Knowles

results.title: African Wildlife
results.brief_description: Witness the realities of birth, death and survival in a vivid encounter with the animal world. Filmed in Namibia’s Etosha National Park over the course of two years, the film captures extraordinary close-ups of animal behaviour, a wildebeest giving birth, a zebra mother successfully defending her foal from the swift attack of a cheetah, and a young springbok alerting his herd to the presence of a predator with stiff-legged leaps.

results.title: African violets
results.brief_description: This program looks at the large range of African violets and Streptocarpus (Cape Primrose) available, and their care. British gardening experts Rev. Tony Clements and Anne Swithinbank demonstrate propagation by leaf cuttings and division. Correct potting techniques as well as hybridisations by cross-pollination are shown. The common pests and diseases affecting African violets are discussed, as well as the watering techniques and best growing conditions to encourage abundant flowers on these popular plants from Tanzania.

results.title: African village life: fishing on the Niger River
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation, Julien Bryan and Hermann Schlenker
results.brief_description: Shows how Bozo tribesmen in Mali, West Africa, obtain one of their most important food staples from the Niger River, using the most primitive kind of equipment. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
